Award.AwardTitle: Spectral Algorithms: From Theory to Practice

Award.AbstractNarration:
The workshop on "Taking Spectral Algorithms from Theory to Practice" is to be held at the Simons Institute for the Theory of Computing, Berkeley, CA, on October 27-31, 2014. The workshop will explore the applicability of recent developments in spectral graph theory to graph partitioning problems that arise in areas such as image segmentation, machine learning, and scientific computing.

The funds ($30,000) will be used to support the participation of approximately 25 attendees in the workshop. Airfare and lodging will be reimbursed. Participation by women and members of underrepresented minorities will be a factor in the selection.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The second workshop of the thematic semester on Algorithmic Spectral Graph Theory at the Simons Institute, entitled “Spectral Algorithms: From Theory to Practice” and co-organized by Misha Belkin (Ohio State University; co-chair), James R. Lee (University of Washington; co-chair), Mauro Maggioni (Duke University), Gary Miller (Carnegie Mellon University), took place the week of Oct. 27 – Oct. 31, 2014.  The workshop was devoted to the study of spectral algorithms, their properties, and applications in various domains including machine learning, statistics, computer vision and applied mathematics. The basic premise of the spectral method is that eigenvalues and eigenfunctions of appropriate operators carry important information about the underlying objects, from graphs to manifolds to datasets. Algorithms and analyses based on this premise have seen great success in computer science, mathematics and many other areas of theory and practice. In this workshop we attempted to bring together and facilitate interactions of researchers from different communities involved in various theoretical and practical aspects of spectral methods, in particular spectral graph methods.  We invited theoretical computer scientists, experts in machine learning, mathematicians and statisticians to introduce various aspects of the larger picture. Our goal was three-fold. First, we wanted to bring important recent progress in the theoretical aspects of spectral methods to the attention of the applied researchers with the expectation that some theoretical ideas will find new applications of practical significance. Second, we believe that problems arising in other areas of science and applications represent interesting and important challenges for computer scientists working in spectral methods. Finally, approaches based on spectral methods are ubiquitous in a broad range of practical and theoretical endeavors, which may benefit from additional interdisciplinary interactions.

The workshop took place over the course of five days. Our goal was to maintain a relatively relaxed schedule with plenty of breaks and opportunities for discussion. About half of the invited participants gave talks.  Since a key purpose of the workshop was to bring together different communities, we aimed each day to have a good mixture of applied and theoretical talks and talks pertaining to different areas. For example, on the first day Ravi Kannan started the workshop by talking about applications of spectral methods to the recovery of parameters of topic models, a direction of extensive recent research in machine learning, which is also generating significant interest in theoretical CS. This was followed by a talk by Moses Charikar on the intriguing phenomenon that exact recovery can in some circumstances be achieved by a convex relaxation. Bin Yu gave an applied talk on regularized spectral clustering and its applications. In the afternoon, Mauro Maggioni and Risi Kondor gave talks on different aspects of multiscale analysis on graphs and its applications to data analysis.

The workshop addressed a number of important directions within the broad scope of spectral methods, which we now outline.

One of the key topics covered was spectral graph clustering.
